data.text: Contents
Introduction
Viral haemorrhagic fevers (VHFs) are severe and life-threatening diseases caused by a range of viruses. VHFs are endemic in parts of Africa, South America, the Middle East and Eastern Europe.

If a patient is suspected, following risk assessment, to be “Low Possibility of VHF”, “High Possibility of VHF” or confirmed as having a VHF, the Infection Prevention & Control Team and Consultant Microbiologist , if out-of-hours, the Consultant Microbiologist on-call) must be informed by the medical team looking after the patient immediately for discussion of appropriate Infection Prevention & Control measures. Other relatively common causes of febrile illness in travellers returning from Africa or other high risk countries include typhoid fever, dengue, Rickettsial infections, malaria and other tropical parasites. Multiple infections are not uncommon in the tropics and the finding of malarial parasites does not absolutely exclude one of the haemorrhagic fevers or other serious infections. As considered appropriate, the Consultant Microbiologist will discuss the case with either the Royal Free Infectious Diseases team and/or the Special Pathogens Reference Unit (SPRU) at the Public Health England (PHE) Centre for Emergency Preparedness and Response at Porton Down, together with notifying the local PHE Health Protection Unit (HPU) team.
The following websites contain information related to VHFs and updates on current cases and outbreaks of infectious disease including VHFs and can be used as an aid to risk assessment:
http://www.hpa.org.uk/Topics/InfectiousDiseases/InfectionsAZ/ViralHaemorrhagicFe ver
http://www.healthmap.org/promed/
Important contact numbers
Consultant Microbiologist – contact via switchboard
Royal Free Hospital (HSIDU) - Tel: 0207 7940500 (Ask for: Infectious Disease Doctor on-call)
High Security Infectious Disease Viral Diagnostic Laboratory - Tel: 0208 2004400

VHFs are caused by a diverse group of Viruses which can cause an array of illnesses from relatively mild to severe and life threatening. Humans are not the natural hosts of the viruses but they become infected after contact with an infected host reservoir, e.g. rodents or arthropod vectors. Transmission between humans is also possible and is the main risk of importing the viruses to different areas or countries where infection by natural host is unlikely.
VHFs are of particular public health importance because:
They can spread readily within a hospital setting.
They have a high case-fatality rate.
They are difficult to recognise and detect rapidly.
There is no effective treatment.
The table below indicates those VHFs that are caused by pathogens classified by the Advisory Committee on Dangerous Pathogens (ACDP) as Hazard Group 4
Arenaviridae Bunyaviridae

The main routes of transmission are:
Direct contact through broken skin or mucous membrane with blood or body fluids.
Indirect contact with environments contaminated with splashes or droplets of blood or body fluids.
Geographical Distribution

1.9.1 VHFs are severe and life-threatening viral diseases that are endemic in parts of Africa, South America, the Middle East and Eastern Europe. All recorded cases of VHF in the UK have been acquired abroad, with one exception of a laboratory worker who sustained a needle-stick injury. There have to date been no cases of person-to-person transmission within the UK.

data.text: Scope

This  policy  describes  when  to  consider  VHF,  the  procedure  for  transfer  to  a specialist unit and the precautions to follow in such circumstances. It is based on international guidance and in particular the outcome of the UK- wide review of VHF management by the Advisory Committee on Dangerous Pathogens.
Definitions

These are members of the filovirus family. These two viruses cause the most severe forms of haemorrhagic fever. The first outbreak of Marburg disease was in a number of laboratory workers in Marburg (Yugoslavia) and Frankfurt, (Germany). The first known cases of Ebola occurred in 1976 in Zaire and Sudan. Since March 2014, West Africa has experienced the largest outbreak of Ebola in history, with multiple countries affected(https://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/outbreaks/2014-west -

Acute VHF which is caused by the Lassa virus, a member of the arenavirus. The disease was first described in the 1950's and was identified in 1969 when two missionary nurses died from it in the town of Lassa in Nigeria

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust

Infection Prevention and Control Site Committee's (IPCC's) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors
The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) will have operational responsibly for the effective implementation of this policy

The Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy, advising ward staff on control measures, and providing them with the necessary advice

All Staff must comply with this policy and act in a responsible manner, liaising with the IPCT in a timely manner if in need of advice or support. All staff have a responsibility to ensure that infection prevention and control is embedded into their everyday practice and applied consistently at all times
Diagnosis

In the early stages of the illness there may be no specific clinical features and so the diagnosis must be considered in anyone who develops an unexplained fever within three weeks of returning from the areas listed in the introduction.
The following information should be established from the patient:
Countries and towns visited.
The purpose of the visit.
Did the visit involve visiting rural areas?
Did the patient have contact with illness consistent with VHF?
Did the patient have contact with rats or other rodents?
Did the patient eat bush meat or import any into the country?
Did the patient take anti-malarials regularly? If yes obtain details.
Date of return to the UK.
Date of onset of illness.
Details of illness
Clinical features may include: fever, headache, myalgia, pharyngitis, diarrhoea, bloody diarrhoea, vomiting, rash, bleeding, shock, lymphopaenia, thrombocytopaenia and raised AST.
Infectivity

Dependant on the virus, modes of transmission can include blood, urine, semen, vomit, faeces, tick bites. There has been no evidence of aerosol transmission from VHF patients. If there is no immediate threat to life (malaria being excluded), patients may remain at home. Patients can be managed more effectively if they are categorised according to level of infectivity and risk.
Risk Assessment

The Consultant Microbiologist /Virologist should be notified as soon as possible and preferably before the patient is admitted to assess the level of risk and determine whether admission locally is appropriate.
Minimum risk category
Includes febrile patients who have a history of foreign travel but have not been to an endemic area , or
Patients who have been in endemic areas or have been in contact with a known or suspected source of VHF, but in whom the onset of illness occurred more than  days after contact.
Moderate risk category
Includes febrile patients that have been in an endemic area during the  days before the onset of illness, but have none of the additional risk factors that place them in the high risk category, or

Patients who have not been in a known endemic area but who may have been in adjacent areas or countries during the  days before the onset of illness, and who have evidence of severe illness with organ failure and/or haemorrhage which could be due to VHF, and for which no alternative diagnosis is currently evident.
High risk category
Includes febrile patients who have been in an endemic area within  days before illness and:
Have household contact for more than four hours with people who are known or suspected of having a VHF or
Nursed or cared for patients known or suspected of having a VHF or
Are a laboratory worker who has had contact with body fluids or tissues of a human or animal known or strongly suspected of having VHF or
Were previously categorised as ‘moderate' risk, but who have developed organ failure and/or haemorrhage.

Patients who  have not been in an endemic area  will also be considered a high risk if they cared for a patient or animal known or strongly suspected of having a VHF, or came into contact with their bodily fluids or tissue  days preceding illness, or
Handled clinical specimens known or strongly suspected to contain a VHF virus

Management of patients categorised as ‘VHF unlikely'

Manage using standard infection control precautions. If the patient develops bleeding, sudden fall in platelets or a rise in AST, shock or unexplained rise in O2 requirement then reconsider the categorisation.
As per guidance link
Management of patients categorised as ‘possible VHF'
As per guidance link

Discuss with the Royal Free Infectious Disease Unit London. This patient should be transferred to the High Security Infectious Disease Unit as a priority. They can be contacted 24 hours a day on 0207 794 0500 or 0844 848 0700.
Infection Control Measures:
Isolation
13.1.1  The patient should be isolated in a single side room. This should be in the Emergency Department.
Personal Protective Equipment

Details are given in the National Guidance and should be discussed with detail by the Infection Prevention and Control Department. If the patient has bleeding, bruising, diarrhoea, vomiting or cough then: gloves, apron, face mask, visors are recommended. If aerosol or splash generating procedures are undertaken then a FFP3 mask is also required. Otherwise normal standard precautions are sufficient.
Laundry /linen
Linen should be disposed of as contaminated waste. This should be placed in an orange clinical waste bag.
Clinical waste
This should be disposed of as Category B clinical waste following the normal procedures described in the waste policy.
Clinical samples
Patient will require an urgent malaria investigation.

When dealing with blood and other body fluids and tissue samples, no special precautions are required (refer to national guidance). Clinical waste generated by taking the samples, or in the lab, should be treated as clinical waste as normal. Sample can be analysed in closed analysers with category 2 precautions.
Duration
Precautions should continue until a firm alternative diagnosis is made or the patient is well.
Clinical Management
Most possible VHF cases have another condition, usually an infection such as malaria.
The possible VHF should not delay the full investigation and management of other infections.
Management of patients Categorised as ‘high possibility of VHF'
19.3.1 As per guidance link

19.3.2 Management should be led by a senior clinician and fully involve the Direction of Infection Prevention and Control and or the Consultant Microbiologist and the Infection Prevention and Control Team. The aim of management is to prepare the patient for transfer to the High Security Infectious Disease Unit while protecting other patients and staff.
The patient will require an urgent malaria investigation, then:
Discuss with Infection Consultant (Infectious Disease/Microbiology/Virology)
Infection Consultant to arrange VHF screen with Imported Fever Service (0844 7788990)
Notify Local Health Protection Unit
Consider empiric antimicrobials
Infection Control Measures:
Isolation
20.1.1 The patient should be isolated as described in the isolation Policy. This should be in the Emergency Department .The patient must use a dedicated commode, not en- suite facilities
Personal Protective Equipment

20.2.1  Details are given in the national guidance and will be discussed in detail by the Duty Infection Control staff. If the patient has bleeding, bruising, diarrhoea, vomiting or cough then: double gloves, fluid repellent disposable gown, visor, FFP3 mask. Where none of these symptoms are present gloves, apron, surgical face mask and visor are recommended. If aerosol or splash generating procedures are undertaken then an FFP3 mask would be required.
Laundry
20.3.1  Laundry should be disposed of as contaminated waste. Visibly soiled laundry should be disposed of as clinical waste.
Clinical waste
20.4.1  This should be disposed of as Category A clinical waste. Arrangements will be made through the Infection Control Team and Waste Manager. This waste will be disposed by specialist contractor.
Clinical samples

20.5.1 Clinical samples e.g. blood and other body fluids and tissue samples. Samples should be kept to a minimum and discussed with the relevant lab prior to being sent. Samples should be transported in a suitable sealed container.
20.5.2 Samples MUST NOT be sent via the pneumatic transport system.

20.5.3 Gloves and an apron should be worn when handling or transporting such samples. In the laboratory a visor should also be worn. Clinical waste generated by taking the samples to, or in the lab, should be treated as category A clinical waste. Samples should be decontaminated where possible prior to analysis. The National Guidance provides details of the precautions for laboratory procedures.
Duration
20.6.1  Precautions should continue until the patient is well/ transferred to the High Security Infectious Disease Unit.
Clinical Management

20.7.1 An urgent VHF screen (EDTA and a serology sample) should be sent to the HPA reference laboratory. Contact details in section 7.35 and in the National Guidance. The reference lab should be informed that the samples are to be sent and will discuss transport arrangements.
20.7.2 Results should be available within 6 hours of receipt.
20.7.3 If the results are negative the patient should be managed as ‘possible VHF' as in 4 above.
Management of Patents Categorised as having VHF
20.8.1  Details of management of confirmed VHF are described in the National Guidance and will not be undertaken at any of the MSE sites
Transfer to the High Security Infectious Disease Unit
20.9.1 This should be undertaken when a patient is categorised as ‘possible' VHF and requires transfer to the High Security ID Unit or as ‘possible VHF'.
20.9.2 The patient should be transferred wearing a surgical face mask
20.9.3 Staff should wear the PPE as appropriate to the patient's risk stratification

20.9.4 Transfer should be as direct and prompt as possible. Staff should be designated to call and keep a lift and ensure visitors and other staff maintain a safe distance (for practical purposes at least one and ideally two meters).

20.9.5 Transfer can only be undertaken in an ambulance category 4 vehicle. The London Ambulance Service will make the necessary arrangements and should be contacted as soon as VHF is suspected to avoid delays.
Cleaning and Decontamination
This is described in detail in the national guidance. In brief:
Cleaning should:
Be undertaken promptly
Be undertaken using PPE appropriate to the risk classification of the patient
Areas requiring such cleaning should be identified promptly and discussed with the IPCT
Decontamination of visible spills of body fluid should be undertaken as described in the Management of Blood and Other Body Fluid Spillages policy
Cleaning should use 1,000ppm free chlorine.
Commodes should be considered as of particular infection risk.
These should be cleaned with 1000ppm available chlorine after each use and on patient discharge. The ICT will ensure the availability of a suitable product.
Communications

Clinical staff suspecting VHF should immediately discuss the case with the Consultant Microbiologist and Infectious Disease Consultant. The Consultant responsible for the patient or on call Consultant should then be contacted, and be fully involved in all subsequent discussions. Either the Consultant responsible or the Consultant Microbiologist should then contact the High Security ID Unit who are available 24 hours on 0207 794 0500 or 0844 848 0700

The Duty Microbiologist will also contact other appropriate members of the Infection Control Team to ensure enough support is being provided including, the Hospital Duty Manager, Clinical Site Manager and Public Health.
Incident Meeting

It is expected that most patients will stay only a short time in the Emergency Department prior to transfer. A debrief Incident Meeting attended by those involved should be arranged as soon as possible. It should address whether all precautions were in place and whether all potential risk has been
Training Requirements
All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates and Donning and Doffing updates.

The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs
